Message.Msg: THis should be under $200 soon!!!! lol

Post-splits, that would mean that you bought those shares in1974. So are you saying that you purchased stock in 1974 that would now be equal to 40,000 shrs at $10? Or are you saying that you paid $10 for a XXX shares that now totals 40,000 after all splits - because the last time the pre-split price for IBM fell to $10 was before you were born. So I assume it's the former, and you are claiming you purchased at a post-many-splits price of $10 in 1974???

Not that hard to believe actually. Not all the splits were 2 for 1. Albert Einstein said that compounding was the 8th wonder of the world and so true it is. I feel sorry for young people today, who are bombarded with the advertising to trade, trade, trade and they never hold on to anything long enough to get their compounding rewards. Compounding accounts for 54% of all long term capital gains. Stocks will always go up and down, so if you're reinvesting your dividends and adding cash regularly, you're always buying at market value, no matter where the price is on a short term basis. Price doesn't matter, value does. Read some books by Bogle, Berstein, Malkiel, Shultheis, Buffett and scores of others who have been there and done that. There's irrefutable facts that prove trading is the way to lose the most.
I held but its very boring. Just collecting a dividend check is not exciting. I'm thinking of selling but the capital gains tax would kill me.
